articles.description: Fixed: Several style issues
articles.title: v1.14.4

articles.description: style tweak
articles.title: v1.14.3

articles.description:
New: Adjust article grouping based on timezone. You need to add timezone in osmosfeed.yml for accurate grouping. See details in documentation.
New: Card title now toggles card content
New: all toggles on the UI are persisted with local storage. You can use it to track read/unread status within a single browser.
New: Build timestamp now links to the GitHub Action run
Changed: Sources are sorted based on publish time rather than alphabetical order
Changed: Style adjusted for easier reading
Fixed: Horizontal overflow on Safari
Fixed: HTML syntax error in default template
articles.title: v1.14.2

articles.description: git typo in gh run url
articles.title: v1.14.1

articles.description:
New: Adjust article grouping based on timezone. You need to add timezone in osmosfeed.yml for accurate grouping. See details in documentation.
New: Card title now toggles card content
New: all toggles on the UI are persisted with local storage. You can use it to track read/unread status within a single browser.
New: Build timestamp now links to the GitHub Action run
Changed: Sources are sorted based on publish time rather than alphabetical order
Changed: Style adjusted for easier reading
Fixed: Horizontal overflow on Safari
Fixed: HTML syntax error in default template
articles.title: v1.14.0: V1.14.0 (#79)

articles.description:
New: Thumbnail image display for each article
New: Improved color, spacing, and typography for easier reading
New: Click the date to toggle all accordions on that day. Ctrl + Click to toggle all accordions on the entire site.
Changed: All sections are expanded by default
Changed: Switched to vitest for easier testing
Fixed: Long string (e.g. URL) caused horizontal overflow
Thank you: @naari3, @tianheg
articles.title: v1.13.0

articles.description:
Fixed: Future articles appeared in the feed
Fxied: Security vulnerability from axios
Thank you: @naari3

articles.description:
I have a handful of good links to articles about performance that are burning a hole in my bookmarks folder, and wanna drop them here to share.

From fonts to SVG: an icon migration strategy
‚Ä¶

Here‚Äôs an example where I ‚Ä¶

articles.author: Patrick Brosset
articles.description:
Styling ranges of text in software is a very useful thing to be able to do. Thankfully, we have the CSS Custom Highlight API to look forward to because it represents the future of styling text ranges on the web.‚Ä¶
CSS Custom Highlight API: The Future of Highlighting Text Ranges on the Web originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
Ahmad Shadeed covers the CSS fit-content sizing keyword. It‚Äôs useful! It just doesn‚Äôt come up super often. I find myself using min-content a lot more, like when setting up the height of a grid-template-row.
The fit-content keyword is actually ‚Ä¶
Ahmad Shadeed: Use Cases For CSS fit-content originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Ahmad Shadeed: Use Cases For CSS fit-content

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
I enjoy articles like Hartley Charlton‚Äôs ‚ÄúMicrosoft Edge Looks Set to Overtake Safari as World‚Äôs Second Most Popular Desktop Browser.‚Äù It‚Äôs juicy! We know these massive players in the browser market care very much about their market share, so when ‚Ä¶

articles.description:
We‚Äôve discussed a lot about the internals of using CSS in this ongoing series on web components, but there are a few special pseudo-elements and pseudo-classes that, like good friends, willingly smell your possibly halitotic breath before you go ‚Ä¶
Web Component Pseudo-Classes and Pseudo-Elements are Easier Than You Think originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
A fun deep dive from Zach. Do you have an opinion on which you should use?
1) https://website.com/foo/
2) https://websites.com/foo
The first option has a ‚Äútrailing slash.‚Äù The second does not.
I‚Äôve always preferred this thinking: you use a trailing ‚Ä¶
Trailing Slashes on URLs: Contentious or Settled? originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Trailing Slashes on URLs: Contentious or Settled?

articles.author: ≈†ime Vidas
articles.description:
In my recent article about CSS underline bugs in Chrome, I discussed text-decoration-thickness and text-underline-offset, two relatively new and widely-supported CSS properties that give us more control over the styling of underlines.
Let me demonstrate the usefulness of ‚Ä¶
When to Avoid the text-decoration Shorthand Property originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

articles.description:

Manuel Matuzovic‚Äôs CSS Specificity Demo originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
Nic Chan:
[‚Ä¶] the¬†will-change¬†property landed in major browsers in August 2015, and I‚Äôve been on the lookout for when to use it ever since. It might seem self-evident to apply it to commonly animated properties such 
‚Ä¶
My white whale: A use case for will-change originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: My white whale: A use case for will-change

articles.author: Anand Chowdhary
articles.description:
For the past few weeks, I‚Äôve been hiring for a senior full-stack JavaScript engineer at my rental furniture company, Pabio. Since we‚Äôre a remote team, we conduct our interviews on Zoom, and I‚Äôve observed that some developers are not ‚Ä¶

articles.title: Explain the First 10 Lines of Twitter‚Äôs Source Code to Me

articles.author: ImageEngine
articles.description:
(This is a sponsored post.)
In recent years, the Jamstack methodology for building websites has become increasingly popular. Performance, scalable, and secure, it‚Äôs easy to see why it‚Äôs becoming an attractive way to build websites for developers.
GatsbyJS is ‚Ä¶
Superior Image Optimization: An Ideal Solution Using Gatsby & ImageEngine originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
Kinda silly sounding, isn‚Äôt it? CSS database queries. But, hey, CSS is capable of talking to other languages in the sense that it can set the values of things that they can read. Plus, CSS can request other files, and ‚Ä¶
CSS Database Queries? Sure We Can! originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS Database Queries? Sure We Can!

articles.author: Daniel Yuschick
articles.description:
Let‚Äôs face it: building an AA or AAA-accessible product can be quite daunting. Luckily, having an accessible product isn‚Äôt all-or-nothing. Even seemingly small improvements can have nice quality of life benefits for many people.
In that spirit, here are five ‚Ä¶
5 Accessibility Quick Wins You Can Implement Today originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: 5 Accessibility Quick Wins You Can Implement Today

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
That‚Äôs a damn one-two punch from Dave. He goes for the ultimate clickbait title¬π, then follows up with a pile of epic advice for us all. If you want web browsers to get better, listen up:
Complaining on 
‚Ä¶
Before I go: When it comes to complaining about web browsers originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Before I go: When it comes to complaining about web browsers

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Stephanie Stimac)
articles.description: Dual-screen devices are just the next evolution in responsive design. If you have a PWA or website, the APIs available make integrating into your existing code base seamless. This article explains why it‚Äôs an exciting time for layout on the web, and how dual screens provide an opportunity to get even more creative.
articles.title: Building Web Layouts For Dual-Screen And Foldable Devices

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Jhey Tompkins)
articles.description: What started as a case study turned into a guide to visualizing audio with JavaScript. Although the output demos are in React, Jhey Tompkins isn‚Äôt going to dwell on the React side of things too much. The underlying techniques work with or without React.
articles.title: A Guide To Audio Visualization With JavaScript And GSAP (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Michelle Barker)
articles.description: 2022 is shaping up to be a pretty great year for CSS, with a plethora of new features on the horizon. Some are already starting to land in browsers, others are likely to gain widespread browser support in 2022, while for one or two the process may be a little longer. In this article we‚Äôll take a look at a few of them.
articles.title: New CSS Features In 2022

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: As a design community, we all can‚Äôt be silent in these times. We need to be united in our fight against the war, for democracy, for those dreams that children are entitled to have when they are growing up. It‚Äôs our obligation to help as much as we can. **We are donating all proceeds** from "Interface Design Checklists" PDF to support Ukraine.
articles.title: We All Are Ukraine üá∫üá¶

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Following our monthly tradition, artists and designers from across the globe challenged their creative skills and designed desktop wallpapers to welcome March. They come in versions with and without a calendar and can be downloaded for free.
articles.title: March For Equality (2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (√Åtila Fassina)
articles.description: Maintaining a design system is a lot of work. In this article, Atila Fassina shares his lessons learned and how a platform such as Backlight can help put together a series of tools to speed up your architecture setup.
articles.title: A Recipe For A Good Design System

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (√Åtila Fassina)
articles.description: Web Vitals are the new gold standard in performance due to their direct correlation with the user‚Äôs experience. In this article, you‚Äôll learn what monitoring can do and how RayGun can help you sustain performance maintenance while scaling your app.
articles.title: How To Benchmark And Improve Web Vitals With Real User Metrics

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: If we want our WordPress plugins to offer a settings page that is fully powered by blocks, how can we do it? Since *Full Site Editing* doesn‚Äôt support this feature yet, we need to code a custom solution. In this article, we will learn how we can do it.
articles.title: Using The WordPress Editor And CPTs To Configure Plugins

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ilya Medvedev)
articles.description: How do text typing and editing work on the web? Although this process might seem straightforward, there is a lot of technical nuance behind its apparent simplicity. This article looks at how typing on the web works.
articles.title: How To Develop A Text Editor For The Web

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, we‚Äôre talking about Responsible JavaScript. What does it mean for code to be responsible, and how should we approach projects differently? Drew McLellan talks to expert Jeremy Wagner to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 45 With Jeremy Wagner: What Is Responsible JavaScript?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ramona Schwering)
articles.description: You don‚Äôt need to be a full DevOps engineer if you want to introduce a testing build routine. With the help of some testing frameworks and GitHub actions, Ramona Schwering gives a short kick-off to help you get on the right track.
articles.title: Testing Pipeline 101 For Frontend Testing

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Knut Melv√¶r)
articles.description: Markdown in all its flavors, interpretations, and forks won‚Äôt go away. However, it‚Äôs important to look at emerging content formats that try to encompass modern needs. In this article, Knut shares his advice against Markdown by looking back on why it was introduced in the first place, and by going through some of the major developments of content on the web.
articles.title: Thoughts On Markdown

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: We all need a little inspiration boost every now and again. In this post, we collected inspiring resources from all across the web for you ‚Äî beautiful eye candy, tips to challenge your skills, and useful tools that are bound to spark new ideas. Enjoy!
articles.title: Falling In Love With The Web: Inspiring Websites And Tools

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: In this article, Leonardo Losoviz discusses some potential consequences as well as positive outcomes of WordPress joining the Block Protocol.
articles.title: Implications Of WordPress Joining The Block Protocol

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nick Babich & Gleb Kuznetsov)
articles.description: Voice is a powerful tool that we can use to communicate with each other. This article covers the most critical aspects of designing for voice user interfaces: designing the conversation and designing visual interfaces.
articles.title: Everything You Want To Know About Creating Voice User Interfaces

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Frederick O‚ÄôBrien)
articles.description: This installment of *Web Design Done Well* celebrates weird and wacky websites. Sites with sweet, innocent, sometimes pointless purposes. Are they money makers? Game changers? Not necessarily, but they sure are fun, and in ways only the web could really manage.
articles.title: Web Design Done Well: Perfectly Pointless

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Steven Hoober)
articles.description: In this article, Steven Hoober shines the spotlight on Fitts‚Äô Law and explains why we should always ask questions and consider what particular guidelines and lessons mean to our users and our products.
articles.title: Fitts‚Äô Law In The Touch Era

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sergey Melukov)
articles.description: Statoscope is an instrument that analyses your webpack-bundles. Created by Sergey Melukov, it started out as an experimental version in late 2016, which has now become a full-fledged toolkit for viewing, analyzing, and validating webpack-bundles.
articles.title: Statoscope: A Course Of Intensive Therapy For Your Bundle

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Stanislav Khrustalev)
articles.description: While QR codes have many uses and can be leveraged at many touch points, they are just one of dozens of technologies that can improve the customer‚Äôs journey. Stanislav Khrustalev shares his advice with a list of things to keep in mind when using QR codes for your business.
articles.title: Using QR Codes In Your Business: Best Practices And Pitfalls

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Noam Rosenthal)
articles.description: In this second part, Noam suggests a few patterns of how to use the web platform directly as an alternative to some of the solutions that are offered by frameworks.
articles.title: What Web Frameworks Solve: The Vanilla Alternative (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Michelle Barker)
articles.description: In this article, we‚Äôll look specifically at what we can do to reduce the impact of social media embeds and social sharing widgets ‚Äî or even some strategies to avoid them altogether. While the spotlight is on reducing the environmental impact, many of these tips will be great for performance too.
articles.title: Reducing The Web‚Äôs Carbon Footprint: Optimizing Social Media Embeds

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: In this article, Adrian Bece shares more about the benefits and caveats of code-splitting and how page performance and load times can be improved by dynamically loading expensive, non-critical JavaScript bundles.
articles.title: Improving JavaScript Bundle Performance With Code-Splitting

articles.author: Dionysia Lemonaki
articles.description: In this article, you'll learn how to use Python's built-in remove() list method. By the end, you'll know how to use remove() to remove an item from a list in Python. Here is what we will cover:  1. Syntax of the remove() method  2. Remove an element from
articles.title: Python List .remove() - How to Remove an Item from a List in Python

articles.author: Jose Vicente Nunez
articles.description: Everything is connected to wireless these days. In my case I found that I have LOTS of devices after running a simple nmap command on my home network [/news/enhance-nmap-with-python/#nmap-101-identify-all-the-public-services-in-our-network] : [josevnz@dmaf5 ~]$ sudo nmap -v -n -p- -sT -sV -O --osscan-limit --max-os-tries 1 -oX $HOME/home_scan.xml 192.168.1.0/24 So I started to
articles.title: How to Secure Your Home Wireless Infrastructure with Kismet and Python

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: Creating your own eCommerce website is easier than you may think. You don't even need to know how to code. I just created and published a course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you how to build an online store with WooCommerce and WordPress. In this video course,
articles.title: How to Create an eCommerce Website Using WooCommerce

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: GitLab CI/CD can automatically build, test, deploy, and monitor your applications. We just published a full course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you how to use GitLab CI. Valentin Despa developed this course. Vaentin is an experienced developer and course creator. In this course, you will learn
articles.title: DevOps with GitLab CI Course

articles.author: Daniel Rosa
articles.description: In this article, you'll learn how to work with JavaScript in the backend using Node on Windows. When you start working with JavaScript and discover that you can not only work with it in the frontend but also in the backend, a new world of possibilities seems to open up
articles.title: How to Install Node.js and npm on Windows

articles.author: Paul Akinyemi
articles.description: In this article, you will be recreating the guessing game Wordle [https://www.nytimes.com/games/wordle/index.html]. This article covers the core game logic but does not implement sharing your results. The article also doesn't cover the functionality that generates game statistics.  This tutorial is intended for beginner front-end developers that want to build
articles.title: How to Build a Wordle Clone in JavaScript

articles.author: David Clinton
articles.description: The Internet of Things (IoT) is a term that has been floating around for a few years now, but what does it actually mean?  The best way to describe the IoT is to think of it as the network of physical objects that are interconnected and can communicate with
articles.title: IoT Deployment ‚Äì How to Secure and Deploy Internet of Things Devices

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: The Node Package Manager (NPM) provides various commands that let you work with packages. And just as you can install a package from the npm library, you can uninstall it. To uninstall a package, you can use the command provided by npm for the purpose ‚Äì npm uninstall. The way
articles.title: npm Uninstall ‚Äì How to Remove a Package

articles.author: Reed Barger
articles.description: If you have trouble understanding the useEffect hook, you're not alone. Beginners and experienced developers alike find it to be one of the trickiest hooks to understand, because it requires understanding a few unfamiliar programming concepts. In this quick guide, we're going to cover why this hook exists, how to
articles.title: The React useEffect Hook for Absolute Beginners

articles.author: Dionysia Lemonaki
articles.description: In this article, you'll learn how to use Python's built-in pop() list method. By the end, you'll know how to use pop() to remove an item from a list in Python. Here is what we will cover:  1. An overview of lists in Python  2.  How to
articles.title: Python .pop() ‚Äì How to Pop from a List or an Array in Python
